top.value: Christian Aid, 35-41 Lower Marsh, London SE1 7RL, United Kingdom

The goal of the CASE-OVC program is to ensure that children affected by HIV/AIDS are resilient and thriving within their households and communities. This will be achieved when OVC and their households demand, seek and gain sustained access to health and social services; households have improved access to sustainable livelihood options and their caregiving and protection capacity is enhanced; and finally when an enabling environment is created to foster transformational change by ensuring that systems and structures for child welfare are responsive, inclusive and accountable to the needs of OVC. The program will provide services to an estimated 170,000 OVC in 52,000 households in 18 counties in Kenya.

Christian Aid aims to engage with and support EVD affected households and communities to reduce the transmission of the disease, meet immediate needs and mitigate the suffering caused by the Ebola Crisis.

The overall GOAL of the programme is to achieve safe and secure shelter, food security, water sanitation and hygiene, and livelihoods for the most affected households in targeted VDCs in 3 heavily affected Districts of Nepal.

Christian Aid through partners had responded as part of the rapid response actions in Gorkha, Dhading, Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha. The needs assessment has indicated that the affected communities continue to have needs of recovery and winterization in the immediate context, particularly in more remote VDCs which were difficult to access in inclement weather conditions including winter and monsoon. The areas identified of recovery actions include the following: 
• Repair and rehabilitation of destroyed/ dysfunctional water schemes : Component 01 

• Technical guidance for safer shelter and winterization provision: Component 02
• Livelihoods recovery actions for sustainable development : Component 03
• Education and DRR mainstreaming to ensure safer culture for future: Component 04 
• Inclusive DRR actions and community participation : Component 05

Main activities include:
-	Build and refine climate services in Burkina Faso in response to user needs

-	Increase availability and quality of relevant information on weather and climate change at national level
-	Increase availability and quality of relevant information on weather and climate change at local level
-	Local Participatory Approach for risk management
-	Building local productive capacity through implementation of Soils and Water Conservation activities to mitigate climate risk 
-	Development, support and monitoring of IGA for the diversification of income sources 
-	Multi-seasonal promotion of market garden production & diet diversification
-	Mitigation of climate-related prices increase  for the poorest
-	BRACED Participatory Approach for institutional risk management in 13 communes 
-	Collective community mobilization for disaster risk reduction
-	Conflict prevention on pastoral resources (water, land, fodder)
-	Community awareness on practical solutions to build nutritional resilience
-	Academic and policy research agenda
-	Spaces for internal and external dialogue, advocacy and learning
-	Specific impact studies on good practices to face climate extremes disasters

BRACED Ethiopia focuses on building the resilience of vulnerable people in Oromia and Southern Nations Nationalities and Peoples Regions (SNNPRs) to climate extremes and disasters. Weather and climate services; tangible resilience building activites encompassing natural resources management, livestock and crops productivity and market chain improvement; local capacity building; and documentation of lessons and sharing are key activities of the project

Implementation of the activities will result in establishment of Community friendly climate knowledge exchange mechanisms which convey regular, reliable and understandable information about climate change, seasonal forecasting, and practical solutions to build resilience. It will also support communities with relevant community level interventions designed to reduce their vulnerability to climate risks and vulnerabilities.The intervention increases capacity of local actors to respond to climate extremes and disasters and contributes to improved understanding of what works in building resilience to climate extremes and disasters.The eventual outcome of these immediate results will be improved resilience of communities to climate extremes and disasters and improved knowledge and evidence base for building resilience to climate extremes and disasters within sector and with other actors.

ERFS (Emergency Response Fund Scheme) funding is pre-positioned emergency funding designed to be used in immediate first phase emergency response work during sudden onset humanitarian crises.  Important factors to consider when deciding whether to draw down funds include: scale of the crisis, our capacity to respond, leverage for other funding, timing for rapid response (should be immediately/very soon after sudden onset).

Expected Outcomes Total project of 6 partners
3,060  survivors  and   other   vulnerable   people   severely   affected   by   the      Ebola  virus  will   have  the   ability   to 

support themselves with vital access to food, without which they cannot survive. The project will also have a 
knock on effect on thousands of other people by bringing down the price of food and making it more widely 
available   to   others  in   the  community.  Many   Ebola   survivors   have   been   left   with   nothing,  their  homes   and 
belongings  having been destroyed  in the decontamination process, and therefore this project  will  also  help 
restore their dignity and hope for the future, which is of crucial  importance as the stigma suffered  by Ebola 
survivors remains rife. This project will enable the families to move forward and build a new life, free of Ebola.
